note.p: This is a personal, untitled letter, written with ink on the front and back side of one approximately 7.5 inch by 10 inch sheet of lined paper.

William B. Anderson's letter dated July 31, 1863, from Cincinnati and addressed to his wife Mary Louisa is written in dark ink on both sides of a loose sheet of paper measuring approximately 7.5 inches wide by 10.0 inches tall (19.5 x 25 cm) and ruled with horizontal blue lines spaced .33 inches (0.8 cm) apart, except for a 1.5-inch (3.8 cm) unruled top margin on the front of the sheet and a 0.9-inch (2 cm) unruled top margin on the back of the sheet. The left edge of the sheet is slightly ragged, while the other three edges are straight, suggesting that the sheet was torn from a notepad or bound notebook. It appears to have been folded once crosswise and twice lengthwise. At this writing, the ink appears very dark brown and the paper off-white (cream). A .5-inch by .5-inch (1.3 x 1.3 cm) embossed printer's mark appears in the upper lefthand corner of the sheet, 0.5 inches (1.3 cm) from the top edge and .25 inches (0.6 cm) from the left edge. Although the mark is hard to see, its shape closely matches that of a distinct, similarly sized and positioned printer's mark on a letter dated July 1, 1863, which reads "MT HOLLY PAPER CO." (see illustrations), so it is likely this letter was of the same paper supply. The Ohio State University Library's Rare Books and Manuscripts Library is currently inaccessible due to its relocation in preparation for renovation, so no further information about the original letter is currently available.

projectDesc.p: William B. Anderson's letter to his wife Mary Louisa on July 31, 1863 seems mundane, yet its very unpretentiousness makes the letter touching. In the letter he speaks of a sick acquaintance, money to be earned or brought home, details of his commission from the government, and the type of goods he is carrying down the Ohio River. He also expresses the hope that he will be able to spend the winter at home with his family. The letter is hurried, but contains many details of interest to both scholars and the general public, as well as any descendents of the Andersons.

In Anderson's protests to his wife that he has been writing regularly, one can feel how the separation — an element natural to his employment, but exacerbated by the danger and unpredictability of war — affects the entire Anderson family. According to Dr. Elizabeth Hewitt, professor of American literature at The Ohio State University, "the letter form really forces attention to separations, in this case between family members." Letters are, by nature, used to communicate across separations in time and space, but the anxiety pervading Anderson's letters shows that this is no ordinary separation. With only Anderson's side of the correspondence available, a reader may nevertheless infer from his words that Mary Louisa has been eagerly waiting for letters from him and writing often, probably worried about his safety; after all, he is working close to a war zone. The fact that these letters were preserved in the first place is a testament to their importance to Mrs. Anderson.

Sensitive to his wife's need to hear from him, Anderson writes often (by his account, at least twice a week) to try and reassure her, even though he believes he has "but little news to write about" in this letter at least. He is often so rushed that he cannot write the kind of thoughtful letter he would clearly prefer (and knows his wife would appreciate), frequently apologizing for his haste and saying he has been very busy. He almost always sends a greeting for his children; in the July 31 letter, he asks his wife to "kiss all the little ones for me and tell them to be good" — a poignant glimpse of a devoted father who would much rather be able to kiss his own children in person. In Anderson's stated hope that he will be able to spend the winter at home, one can see how the uncertainty of both his work and the war has set up the home fire as an ideal of rest, safety, and comfort, a sentiment that can be appreciated by any family undergoing a separation. In this respect, the letter validates the Ohio State University Library's objective of collecting individuals' letters written during wartime to represent "the common man's view of great events" (Smith) – a view that is certainly reflected in William B. Anderson's letters to his wife. Anderson’s mention of the Morgan raid’s possible impact on mail delivery in the July 31 letter shows another aspect of how this particular “common man” and his family experienced the Civil War.

This digital edition of Anderson's July 31, 1863 letter could be of use to scholars in multiple fields, as well as to anyone with an interest in the historical, cultural, and social phenomena of mid-19th-century America. Scholars interested in specific dollar amounts paid by the government for the service of a river captain ($150 per day plus fuel, apparently a decent pay rate, as Anderson states it is "as good or better" than what he could get in a civilian employment) would find this letter a valuable resource. The letter would also be of interest to scholars of military history. Anderson gets his orders from the government and is more or less compelled to obey them, as seen from his initial description of being "pressed" into service, which he amends to "chartered" later in the letter. He also is not sure of the duration of the service or what he will be asked to do after he makes this trip to Nashville. His mention of the Morgan raid's possible effect on the mail delivery would be of interest to Civil War historians particularly. River or boat historians might also find this letter useful, as Anderson gives an estimate of the time it will take him to travel from Cincinnati to Nashville (between 15 and 20 days). Persons interested in 19th century American correspondence would also be interested to note how Anderson follows some conventions of standard letter writing, such as particular greetings and closings, while omitting most punctuation — a rule of letter-writing guidebooks that was frequently broken even by those not in Anderson's unique circumstances (Hewitt). The potential value of Anderson’s letters is immeasurable.

Attempting to create a digital edition of these artifacts raises unique considerations. Because it is not actually possible to create a precise reproduction of any original work, especially when working in a different medium than the original work and not directly from the original artifact, this digital edition represents only one interpretation of the letter. Any reader of this digital edition should keep in mind the many inevitably subjective decisions made by the editor, as "texts remain, in the last analysis, ambiguous" (McGann and Buzzetti).

editorialDecl.p: Encoding of the Anderson letters emphasizes diplomatic transcription, with supplemental information allowing for semi-modernized, corrected, regularized, or expanded views included as the values of attributes associated with various elements. Accordingly, abbreviations, recoverable cancelations, punctuation, spelling, underscoring, capitalization, line breaks, and page breaks have all been transcribed or tagged as they appear in the original manuscripts. Regularized versions of all names and referring strings have been encoded as the values of "reg" attributes. Standard format values for all dates have been encoded in "value" attributes.

Corrections and emendations in Anderson's hand have been encoded as cancelations and interlinear or marginal additions. In a few cases, omitted text has been supplied by the editors for the sake of clarity and encoded with the TEI <supplied> element.

The following structural elements of the letters are also encoded: opener (including salutation and dateline), body, lines, paragraphs, pages, and closers (including salutation and signature). Notes and postscripts are identified as such.
The critical apparatus used in particular views of the letters is explained at the bottom of each view.

refsDecl.p: The XML files that constitute this edition of the William B. Anderson letters are named according the letters' dates of composition, using the following naming convention: WBA_YYYYMMDD.xml. Dates of composition were determined from various sources of evidence: the datelines inscribed in the letters, internal evidence in the body of the letters, and perpetual calendars. If the year, month, or date on which a letter was written could not be determined, the appropriate part of the filename is rendered with 0s. XSL style sheet documents are named with the prefix "WBA" followed by an underscore and a descriptive phrase (e.g., "WBA_diplomatic.xsl).

In general, this edition follows the Text Encoding Initiative's Guidelines for Electronic Text Encoding and Interchange, XML-compatible edition P4. For more information about TEI P4, see http://www.tei-c.org/P4X/. To facilitate embedding or linking to image, audio, and video files, this edition supplements the Text Encoding Initiative's DTD by adding a URL attribute to the <xref> element and an MMID (i.e., Media Manager ID) attribute to the <pb> element. The values of the MMID attribute in <pb> elements and the file IDs in the URL attribute of <xref> elements that link to, or embed, image, audio, and video files contained in the Media Manager are generated by the Media Manager application.

bibl.title: Letter from riverboat captain William B. Anderson to his wife at home in Pittsburgh, dated July 31, 1863, from Cincinnati.

div1.p: Anderson informs his wife that the sickly Elias will bring her some money when he returns to Pittsburgh. Anderson then describes his current employment transporting goods for the government. He hopes to make enough money over the summer so that he can stay at home for the winter. While apologizing for an apparent scarcity of letters, Anderson claims that he has written frequently, and speculates that the Morgan raid may have interfered with mail delivery.
Previous letter 18 July 1863 Next letter 01 August 1863

Your of 26 came in due time & I
was pleased to hear from you & hope you & all the
little ones3 are well I send with Elias4 60$ Dolls
as he is going home to stop off till his health
gets better I will see your Mother5 this
Evening I have been very buissily engaged
all day & have not had one moment to
myself I & the boat6 are pressed in Gov.
service or rather chartered at 150$ one
hundred & Fifty Dolls per day & our fuel
furnished which is as good or better than
I could do out of the service our trip
around was rather poor having only
picked put7 but little by the way we
have made in all since the boat came
out six thousand clear cash though that
is not bad in less than two months I hope
to be able to make enough by the setting in
of winter to remain at home & enjoy the com
forts of our own fireside8 though things change often
I had almost despaired when we arrived here and
all of a sudden I happened to strike a luckey
lick & get wind of this opperation that I now
am engaged in we will leave tomorrow
Evening for Nashville9 with 220 Mules and
about 40 tons of soldier clothing & 40 tons of oats
It will take us probably 15 to twenty days to
make the trip & by that time we shall probably
hear of orders to go some place else or it may
be that we shall not be permitted to come
back here again as we are at the Command
of the Military authorities though one thing certain
we are not at our own risk if the boat is
lost we hold the Government for it and the
way it was before if she was lost it would
have been our own risk. I am astonished
to hear of you not receiving more letters
from me for I have written to you very
often 2 the last time I was here and one from
Nashville and so on all the time I am sure
I have written at the very least 2 letters per
week Ever since I left home I hope you
will get them more regularly as I have
written & do still intend writing but there
has been so much trouble about the mails
on account of the Morgan raid10 that I suppose
may account for failure of the mails
I have but little news to write about
Kiss all the little ones for me & tell them to
be good till I come good by till tomorrow I
will drop you a line before we leave

div1.head: Notes
div1.note: 1. Cincinnati, Ohio: a major U.S. city on the Ohio River, situated near the points where the Great Miami, Little Miami, and Licking Rivers all join the Ohio. Because of this confluence of waterways, in the mid-19th century Cincinnati was thriving as an important commercial transfer point for farm goods destined for the South, especially New Orleans. The Ohio River also represented the boundary between North and South during the Civil War. Though Cincinnati sided with the North during the war, it retained strong cultural and economic ties to the South. (Huntington, 256-257; Getty Thesaurus of Geographic Names Online)
2. Mary Louisa Fischgens Anderson, 1837-1911, wife of William B. Anderson; they married in Cincinnati in 1853. (Danker; History of Allegheny County 298)

3. According to information from Anderson descendent Jamie Danker, at the time of this letter the Andersons had four young children: William Y. (Young?), age seven or eight; Anna Margaret, age six; John L., age four; and Robert Edward, age two. A fifth child, Harry C., would be born in January 1865. Tragically, William Y., Robert Edward, and Harry C. would all die of typhoid fever in 1890 (Robert Edward and Harry C. just a day apart), while Anna Margaret and John L. survived the disease that year. In a 2005 report, the Water Science and Technology Board states that Pittsburgh had the highest national typhoid death rate for large cities in the years 1873-1907; before the establishment of an effective water filtration system in 1907, the city drew its drinking water directly from the polluted Allegheny River. (Danker; Regional Cooperation for Water Quality Improvement in Southwestern Pennsylvania 36-37)

4. Elias is unidentified, although he is mentioned in two of Anderson's other letters from the summer of 1863, with further reference to his poor health and having been sent home with $60 for Mrs. Anderson. In the letter of August 1, 1863, William says that he sent the letter of July 31 with Elias rather than through the mail.
5. Mary Louisa's mother, Anna Mary Woolslayer Fischgens, 1812-1897. (Meinert; Danker)
6. William B. Anderson's boat, the Glide (probably Glide No. 2). (History of Allegheny County 298)

7. Anderson apparently began to erroneously write put or pul, then crossed it out and wrote but instead - probably another effect of his haste.
Anderson seemingly began to write put instead of but
Click here to view an image of this detail from the original manuscript

8. Despite opportunities to make more money by running riskier jobs — as mentioned in some of Anderson's other letters — or working later in the year, Anderson's priority is to spend as much time as possible at home with his family.

9. Nashville, Tennessee: Another key city on the 19th-century river commerce routes, located on the Cumberland River. Although Tennessee was part of the South, Nashville was occupied by the Union army during the Civil War.
(Getty Thesaurus of Place Names Online)

10. Confederate general John Hunt Morgan led a series of raids through the southern parts of Indiana and Ohio in July of 1863, inciting fear among the residents of those areas and causing some loss of property. Morgan and some of his men were captured by the Union army on July 26 in Salineville, in eastern Ohio, but later escaped from prison and made their way back to the South. (Ohio History Central)
